docs.lead_paragraph: Following are excerpts from the statements of President Clinton; Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the majority leader, and Speaker Newt Gingrich in announcing the agreement between Democrats and Republicans yesterday on balancing the budget, as provided by the Federal News Service, a private transcription service: President Clinton

headline.main: Statements by Clinton and Congressional Leaders on the Agreement

docs.abstract: Excerpts from statements on budget agreement by Pres Clinton, Sen Trent Lott, majority leader, and Speaker Newt Gingrich (L)
docs.snippet: Following are excerpts from the statements of President Clinton; Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the majority leader, and Speaker Newt Gingrich in announcing the agreement between Democrats and Republicans yesterday on balancing the budget, as...

docs.lead_paragraph: The budget deal shaping up on Capitol Hill would significantly restrain the growth of spending on Medicare, Medicaid and Social Security, further reducing the Federal deficit. But lobbyists for the elderly and governors of both parties said today that they found parts of the agreement unacceptable. Under the agreement, as outlined today by negotiators of both parties, millions of retirees would face higher Medicare premiums and would receive somewhat smaller Social Security checks in future years than they would get under current law.

headline.main: Negotiators Move to Rein In Medicare, Medicaid and Social Security

docs.abstract: Budget deal shaping up on Capitol Hill would significantly restrain growth of spending on Medicare, Medicaid and Social Security, further reducing Federal deficit; lobbyists for elderly and governors of both parties say that they find parts of agreement unacceptable (M)
docs.snippet: The budget deal shaping up on Capitol Hill would significantly restrain the growth of spending on Medicare, Medicaid and Social Security, further reducing the Federal deficit. But lobbyists for the elderly and governors of both parties said today...

docs.lead_paragraph: Time is running out to find a permanent way to reimburse hospitals for treating the uninsured, representatives of the state's 26 urban hospitals said yesterday. The Hospital Alliance of New Jersey found that the institutions themselves are in precarious health because the hospitals are now spending almost as much as they take in, Suzanne Ianni, the organization's executive director, said.
docs.abstract: Hospital Alliance warns that time is runnning out to find permanent way to reimburse state's 26 urban hospitals for treating the uninsured (New Jersey Daily Briefing) (S)
docs.snippet: Time is running out to find a permanent way to reimburse hospitals for treating the uninsured, representatives of the state's 26 urban hospitals said yesterday. The Hospital Alliance of New Jersey found that the institutions themselves are in...

docs.lead_paragraph: White House and Congressional negotiators agreed today on nearly all elements of a plan to balance the Federal budget in five years, but failed to reach a final deal largely because of continuing differences over tax cuts. The emerging deal would give Republicans many of the tax reductions that they have insisted on and the White House the spending that it sought for President Clinton's priorities, including education, health insurance for children and welfare.

headline.main: Clinton and Congress in Accord On Budget, Except for Tax Cuts

docs.abstract: White House and Congressional negotiators agree on nearly all elements of plan to balance Federal budget in five years, but fail to reach final deal largely because of continuing differences over tax cuts; emerging deal will give Republicans many of tax reductions that they have insisted on and White House spending that it seeks for Pres Clinton's priorities; two sides compromise on scaling back Medicare and agree to small reduction in cost-of-living adjustment for Social Security and other Government benefits; spending for domestic programs will decline $68 billion over five years after accounting for inflation, $20 billion more than Clinton had first proposed; deal will contain provisions for $32 billion in new spending on initiatives that White House has demanded; taxes will be cut by $135 billion over five years; photos (M)
docs.snippet: White House and Congressional negotiators agreed today on nearly all elements of a plan to balance the Federal budget in five years, but failed to reach a final deal largely because of continuing differences over tax cuts.    The emerging deal would...

docs.lead_paragraph: The Chevron Corporation will become the first major American oil company to extend domestic partner benefits to most of its 20,000 American employees, regardless of sexual orientation, a spokesman said yesterday. Chevron, which is based in San Francisco, follows a number of other companies that have offered similar programs since the city passed an ordinance in 1996 requiring companies doing business with the city to offer equal benefits to employees' partners. Under Chevron's plan, which is to take effect in January 1998, employees will be able to enroll partners of the same or opposite sex, as well as the partner's eligible children, for a variety of health and other benefits.

headline.main: CHEVRON PLANS TO OFFER DOMESTIC PARTNER BENEFITS
